Most details of the race against Hill are still up in the air — most importantly length and location — though Lyles mentioned 60 meters and New York City's Times Square as possibilities. The summer is also likely for timing, as Lyles will be deep in training for U.S. championships and Hill will be gearing up for the NFL season.
And as far as nerves go, Lyles says the only thing that could make him underperform is fans not getting excited enough.

“I’m more thinking about, 'dang, I have an opportunity to break the world record along with beating Tyreek',” Lyles said. "So Tyreek better be ready, because if a world record gets dropped on his head, he ain’t gonna be able to hear nothing.”

title: Why Meghan Markle just changed the name of her lifestyle brand
summary: Meghan Markle announced she changed the name of her lifestyle brand. Here's why she changed it from American Riviera Orchard to As Ever.
story: Meghan Markle has changed the name of her lifestyle brand from American Riviera Orchard to As Ever.
She announced the news on her official Instagram account on Feb. 18. "Cat's out of the bag. I'm shocked we've kept this a secret for so long," she said.
The Duchess of Sussex explained that the name of the business, first unveiled in March 2024, "limited" her.

"Last year, I had thought that American Riviera sounds like such a great name. It’s my neighborhood. It’s a nickname for Santa Barbara, but it limited me to things that were just manufactured and grown in this area,” she said.
Meghan's announcement comes two weeks before the release of her new Netflix show, "With Love, Meghan," which was rescheduled amid the California wildfires.

"Then Netflix came on, not just as my partner in the show, but as my partner in my business, which was huge. I thought about it, and I've been waiting for a moment to share a name that I had secured in 2022 and this is the moment! And it's called As Ever," Meghan continued.

She explained that As Ever "essentially means as it's always been" and it pays homage to her former lifestyle blog, "The Tig," which she shut down in April 2017, months before she and Prince Harry announced their engagement.

"If you followed me since 2014 with The TIG, you know I've always loved cooking and crafting and gardening," she said. "This is what I do and I haven't been able to share it with you in the same way for the past few years, but now I can. So as things as starting to trickle out there, I wanted you to hear it from me first."
The website for the new business includes a never-before-seen photo of Meghan and her daughter, Lilibet, walking outside in an idyllic green field.
In March 2024, Meghan filed a trademark application extension for her lifestyle brand.

The trademark indicated Meghan will be getting involved with home goods, including tableware, kitchen linens, tablecloths, beverage ware, coffee and tea services and more, as well as perishables like jellies, jams, marmalades, fruit preserves and a variety of spreads and butters.
Additionally, she planned to include items like body soap, body oil, cosmetics and pet shampoo in her brand as well.
A month later, in April, Meghan sent samples of her strawberry jam to people like Chrissy Teigen.
"Of course there will be fruit preserves. I think it's pretty clear by now that jam is my jam," she said in the new video.

title: Backstreet Boys ‘Into the Millennium’ Sphere residency go on sale — how to get tickets
summary: The Backstreet Boys announced their "Into the Millennium" residency at Sphere in Las Vegas to celebrate the 25th anniversary of their "Millennium." Here's everything on how to get tickets, when tour dates are and more.
story: The Backstreet Boys “Into the Millennium” Sphere residency is set to be a larger-than-life event.

The boy band — which consists of Kevin Richardson, AJ McLean, Nick Carter, Howie Dorough and Brian Littrell — is returning to the stage, this time to celebrate a major milestone: the 25th anniversary of their hit album “Millennium.”

The Backstreet Boys initially announced their nine-date “Into the Millennium” Sphere residency on Feb. 12. They later announced that they added three more dates when they made their appearance on TODAY on Feb. 14.
Pre-sales for the 12-date residency are happening now and this week, with general tickets available Feb. 21.

The Backstreet Boys, who are the first pop act to headline at Sphere, are bringing their iconic album to life, alongside a number of their greatest hits and “cutting-edge visuals and sound made possible by Sphere’s revolutionary immersive technology,” per a press release.
“We’re excited to take that album, that concept of the future, to the next level in the most state of the art venue,” Richardson said while on TODAY on Feb. 14.
The name of the residency is a nod to their 1999 and 2000 tour of the same name that supported their third album, “Millennium.”
“Millennium” was released in May 1999 and included their hit songs “I Want It That Way,” “Larger Than Life,” “Show Me the Meaning of Being Lonely” and “The One.”
The singers even paid tribute to the record by re-creating the cover art for the residency’s poster.

Additionally, the group is also releasing a new album, “Millennium 2.0,” which will come out on July 11. The album is a deluxe version of “Millennium” with 25 songs that include the original 12 songs remastered, live recordings, demos and the alternate version of “I Want It That Way.” They also dropped a new song titled “Hey” ahead of the album’s release.
Read on to find out the dates for the Backstreet Boys’ “Into the Millennium” Sphere residency, including the three newly announced dates, and how to get tickets.
What are the Backstreet Boys ‘Into the Millennium’ Sphere residency dates?

The Backstreet Boys initially announced on Feb. 12 that their “Into the Millennium” Sphere residency would have nine dates. However, during their Feb. 14 appearance on TODAY, the boy band revealed that they added three new dates in August.
Here are all the dates of the Backstreet Boys' "Into the Millennium" residency that have been announced so far:
Friday, July 11Saturday, July 12Sunday, July 13Friday, July 18Saturday, July 19Sunday, July 20Friday, July 25Saturday, July 26Sunday, July 27Friday, Aug. 1Saturday, Aug. 2 Sunday, Aug. 3
Friday, July 11
Saturday, July 12
Sunday, July 13
Friday, July 18
Saturday, July 19
Sunday, July 20
Friday, July 25
Saturday, July 26
Sunday, July 27
Friday, Aug. 1
Saturday, Aug. 2
Sunday, Aug. 3
When will tickets for Backstreet Boys 'Into the Millennium' Sphere residency go on sale?
Tickets for the Backstreet Boys “Into the Millennium” Sphere residency go on sale on different dates. General tickets will go on sale Friday, Feb. 21, but there are a couple of presale options.

For the first six shows — July 11, 12, 13, 18, 19, 20 — the Backstreet Boys Fan Club presale will start on Tuesday, Feb. 18 at 9 a.m. PT, followed by the Artist presale on Wednesday, Feb. 19 at 9 a.m. PT. Those interested in participating in the Artist presale can sign up now until Monday, Feb. 17 at 10 p.m. PT.
Then, general onsale tickets will be available starting on Feb. 21 at 9 a.m. PT at backstreetboys.com.
For the other six shows happening July 25-27 and Aug, 1-3, the fan club presale will start on Tuesday, Feb. 18 at 11 a.m. PT, while the Artist presale begins on Wednesday, Feb. 19 at 11 a.m. PT.
Fans who are interested in general onsale tickets for the last three performances will be able to buy starting on Friday, Feb. 21 at 11 a.m. PT at backstreetboys.com.
Vibee, a live entertainment company, is also offering packages for those looking to buy concert tickets and hotel accommodations, which will go on sale on Friday, Feb. 14 at 6 a.m. PT.

Each Vibee package includes either floor or reserved seating tickets at Sphere, two nights at The Venetian Resort Las Vegas or Virgin Hotels Las Vegas, access to a pop-up experience and a Backstreet Boys laminate and lanyard. There is also a VIP option, which provides additional perks such as transportation and priority entry. More information can be found here.
What seat will give you the best experience at Sphere?
For those who have yet to experience a show at Sphere, the Backstreet Boys shared some insight on seat selection.
“There really is no bad seat,” Richardson tells TODAY.com. “It’s just a different experience. If you want a true, more concert-like experience, you can be on the floor.”
He adds that “just above” the floor level, “in the lower bowl looking straight at the screen,” is a good way to take in the whole experience.
“It just depends on where you want to sit,” he says, adding that as far as the sound goes, it will be “amazing no matter where.”

title: How to watch 'A Complete Unknown,' the Bob Dylan biopic that earned 8 Oscar noms
summary: Is "A Complete Unknown" streaming? Here's how to watch the Oscar nominated movie and if it's in theaters and what streaming platform it's on.
story: The Bob Dylan biopic “A Complete Unknown” recently earned eight nominations for the upcoming 2025 Oscars and will be available for home streaming by the end of the month.

The film about the singer-songwriter’s sudden rise to fame in 1960s New York has earned nominations across awards shows, including the Golden Globes and SAG Awards. At the Oscars, “A Complete Unknown” is going up against other films like “Emilia Pérez” and “Wicked” in the best picture category.
For his performance as the Pulitzer Prize-winning artist, Timothée Chalamet became the youngest two-time Oscar nominee since James Dean.

Chalamet plays a 19-year-old Dylan as he shakes up the folk scene and, at the Newport Folk Festival, makes the controversial decision to take up an electric guitar. The actor sang and performed over 40 of Dylan's songs for the film.

“It was important for me to sing and play live. Because if I can actually do it, why should there be an element of artifice here? And I’m proud that we took that leap,” the actor noted in a featurette released before the film premiered.
The film’s producer, Peter Jaysen, revealed on the Ringer podcasst “The Town” that Dylan himself had approval and “meaningful input” over the script.
How to watch 'A Complete Unknown'
Since its release on Christmas Day 2024, “A Complete Unknown” has been available to watch exclusively in movie theaters.
Starting Feb. 25, the film and its never-before-seen bonus extras will arrive on Amazon Prime Video, Apple TV and Fandango at Home for a rental fee.
Additionally on April 1, viewers can bring home a physical or digital copy of the film in 4K UHD Blu-ray and HD Blu-ray.
Since Searchlight Pictures is owned by Disney, it is likely that the film will eventually head to Hulu for U.S. subscribers, like Searchlight Pictures film “A Real Pain” did earlier this year.
TODAY.com has reached out to Searchlight Pictures for comment.

title: Valerie Bertinelli opens up about relationship mistakes: ‘I fumbled the last true good man I met’
summary: Valerie Bertinelli is getting candid about some recent struggles in her love life and offering relationship advice in her latest Instagram post.
story: Valerie Bertinelli is getting candid about some recent struggles in her love life.

The TV personality and actor shared a lengthy post on Instagram Feb. 17 in which she reflected on “mistakes” she has made in past relationships and the “shame” she has felt. She also offered advice to fans who are facing problems with their partners.

Bertinelli, 64, uploaded a selfie on the social media platform and wrote in the caption, “I think about mistakes I’ve made in relationships a lot. I’ve been on both sides of this and I think I finally have some perspective, so I thought I’d share.”
She continued, “When you feel hurt and wronged and know you deserve an apology but are being stonewalled by your partner because they’re feeling shame, maybe this can shift your thinking.”
The former “One Day at a Time” star then listed a few different scenarios and some questions fans should ask themselves when facing a challenging moment in their relationships.

“Are you only pointing out what they’re doing wrong, being hypercritical, and expecting them to just fix it? That could be making things worse,” she pointed out. “Change, real change, never happens through criticism, shame, or pressure. They most likely already feel all that. (I know when I f— up, oof, do I feel shame).”
She cautioned fans to not shut down or get defensive in a heated moment and to instead focus on being empathetic and understanding.

“Maybe try, ‘This is how I feel when this happens, can we figure this out together?’” she suggested. “That one small change can make a difference. Then you’re on the same team. You’re not working *against* each other, you’re working *with* each other.”
Bertinelli acknowledged that being levelheaded in difficult conversations isn’t easy, but she said it will possibly lead to a better outcome.

“I think we all just want to do better and feel awful when we’ve hurt someone we love and shame prevents us from thinking clearly. Wouldn’t it be nice to relieve the one you love from shame so they can truly give you the amends you’re looking for?” she asked.
At the end of her post, she poked fun at some of her past relationships.
“Then again, what do I know,” she cheekily added. “I have two failed marriages and fumbled the last true good man I met. Maybe don’t take advice from me.”
Bertinelli was married to the late Eddie Van Halen from 1981 to 2007. She later tied the knot with financial planner Tom Vitale in 2011, but the two called it quits in 2022.

Since then, the cookbook author has frequently opened up on social media about love and dating. Her last public relationship was with writer Mike Goodnough.  In March 2024, she told People that she was “in love” with someone but didn’t disclose his name at the time. A few weeks later, Goodnough revealed himself as her mystery man on his Substack titled “Hoarse Whisperings.”

“I am Valerie Bertinelli’s boyfriend … and that may well be among the most surreal sentences I’ve ever pecked out,” he wrote at the time. “But it’s true… and nothing about our actual relationship seems surreal. It just seems … good … lucky … a gift.”
In April 2024, they became Instagram official. She shared a sweet selfie of them wearing similar black glasses and quoted lyrics from Taylor Swift’s song “So High School” in the caption.
They continued to share sweet interactions on social media over the next few months and she wished him a happy birthday in August 2024.
But she later stopped posting about him. In November 2024, People reported via a source that Bertinelli and Goodnough had split.

title: 'The White Lotus' just debuted its new theme song and fans would like a word
summary: Fans reacted to the theme song of Season 3 of The White Lotus. What composer Cristobal Tapia de Veer said about the changes.
story: The opening credits of the new season of "The White Lotus" left some fans aghast during the Feb. 16 premiere.
The third season of the hit HBO show has a new song, "Enlightenment," to accompany the opening credits, a strong shakeup from the beloved track "Renaissance" from Season 2.

Though every theme song for "The White Lotus" — including Season 1's "Aloha!" — have been composed by the same person, Cristobal Tapia de Veer, fans are now divided on the song for Season 3, with many not loving the new track.
The song is a departure from the first two seasons, mostly due to the fact that there are no vocals (though the accordion is also making waves).
The echoing, haunting and sometimes outright confusing vocal intonations that have been a featured part of the songs for the first two seasons became part of the weekly viewing ritual.

Though it's been days since the premiere of Season 3, watchers are still posting about the track on social media, sending some fans into a frenzy as they tried to work out how to dance — and not sing — to the song.
"Jail for whoever made the decision to change 'White Lotus' theme song," one person wrote on TikTok as the opening credits played on a TV. "LOCK 'EM UP."
An X user wrote, "New White Lotus theme song doesn’t hit the same should’ve never changed it to begin with sorry to say."
“My disappointment when I didn’t hear this theme song,” one TikToker said. “Okay I was ready to dance... I don’t like this new theme song.”
"Trying to figure out how to dance to the new white lotus theme song," another TikToker wrote.
HBO Max replied in the comments: "You'll get it soon enough."
The comments on an Instagram post from the account for "The White Lotus" featuring the show's opening credits were not much better.
"Respectfully, bring back the theme song wtf is this?" one Instagrammer wrote.
"First, Tanya. Now, this. Good Lord," another user wrote.
"Doodududoo wasn’t just a melody. Doodududoo was THE character," another person wrote. "Justice for Doodududoo!"
However, not all of the comments on the streamer's TikTok post of the opening credits were negative.
"this is honestly pretty dope," one person wrote. "Love the new artwork too."
"I love this theme song though," one TikToker wrote.
"New theme is spellbinding!" another wrote. "Love something new!"
"Tbh I love it the more I hear it," another commenter said, adding the heart-eyed emoji.
"This theme fits the show much better," someone else said. "The first two were too upbeat, this one feels sinister toward the end, ominous too. So good."
And at least one TikToker made their own video in defense of the new song.
"Unpopular belief but I personally love the new intro song for 'The White Lotus,'" the TikToker said. "For some reason this new intro song, and just the overall intro, is so mind blowing."

Will more fans come around to the new track? Only time will tell, but composer Tapia de Veer was ready for a change. He said in a 2023 interview with Variety he initially thought his song for Season 2 was "terrible."

“I took a little time to make an intro that would have those elements with things like a little harp, and some opera singing and some orchestral beats … and once I had that intro I started figuring out how to bring back the elements that are recognizable from the first season, which are the voices,” he said.

Tapia de Veer shared that for his first demo of the track, the original singer wasn't on the song. But he eventually added the distinctive yodeling in, along with more EDM beats, compared to the song for the first season.

“All the elements start slowly changing into an electronic thing. I was just tripping, really, when I started making that beat. It really felt like being in a club and just celebrating with tons of people,” he said.
Tapia de Veer explained that he amped up the song's hype by increasing the energy every four beats.

“When the kick comes in and all of a sudden we’re in a club, it just felt natural that these voices are so powerful, that every bar felt like I could go up one step and then another step,” he said. “The next step it felt like we reached some kind of peak of energy and then you realize the next bar, you could still reach another one and then another one, so it keeps going.”
In an interview with Spotify in 2023, he shared a few details about his composing process for Season 3, which is set in Thailand.

“For Thailand, I want to bring in some Eastern philosophy, something a little bit spiritual,” he said. “I love the Buddhist temples there, and funnily enough I have a collection of Thai gongs. I have 36 Thai gongs to make melodies with, so you can expect to hear some of those. I’d really like to go deep with it, make it take a journey.”

title: Ruby Bridges' new children's book is love letter to her 1st grade teacher: 'She's like another mom to me'
summary: Civil rights icon Ruby Bridges details her friendship with retired teacher Barbara Henry, who is the subject of her new children's book, "Ruby Bridges: A Talk with My Teacher."
story: Civil rights icon Ruby Bridges says she may not have made it through her first year of integrating her all-white public elementary school in 1960, if not for a first grade teacher who became her "best friend."
Nearly 65 years later, that bond is as strong as ever between Bridges and retired teacher Barbara Henry.
"She’s like another mom to me," Bridges said on TODAY on Feb. 18.

The two forged a friendship as teacher and pupil under perilous circumstances at William Frantz Elementary School in New Orleans, and their bond is the subject of Bridges' new children's book. The activist and author is bringing her story to a new generation with "Ruby Bridges: A Talk with My Teacher."

Henry created a sanctuary for Bridges while white protesters outside the building railed against the school being desegregated. Bridges, who was 6 years old at the time, had to be walked into the building by federal marshals amid shouting and threats from white protesters.
Many white families withdrew their children from the school due to her presence, while Bridges previously told TODAY.com that other white students were kept away from her by the school’s principal.
Bridges attended classes alone for a full year, with only Henry there to teach her.

"She filled my day with things to do," Bridges said on TODAY. "She made school fun. I enjoyed learning. Even though the crowd was outside screaming and yelling, she would go to the window and close the window, and she’s say ‘Oh, we’re going to have music today,’ just to drown out everything.
“We often say, both of us, she and I, that despite all the hate that was going on outside, inside that room it was filled with love.”

Henry, who is originally from Boston, would not be dissuaded at a time when many teachers at William Frantz Elementary School quit their jobs or refused to work while a Black child was part of the student body.

"I would not have gotten through that if it had not been for my teacher," Bridges said. "And as you know, teachers really quit their jobs back then because they didn't want to teach Black kids. This one teacher came from Boston to teach me. She was amazing."
Bridges said she was not allowed to go out for recess or eat her lunch in the school cafeteria, which led to her hiding her lunch in Henry's classroom.

"Like any 6-year-old, you want friends," Bridges said. "And I remembered what kindergarten was like, that all of the kids met in the cafeteria, so I thought I’m never going to make friends if I don’t get to the cafeteria.
"That prompted me to hide my sandwiches, until the mice got really bad. And she found the sandwiches, and I was in a world of trouble."
Bridges, 70, realized how important the bond was with Henry when she matriculated to the second grade in the 1961-62 school year.
"I have to say that second grade was much worse for me than first because she was my best friend," Bridges said. "I didn't have any friends, and I had gotten so close to her.
"And I was so excited about going back for second grade, telling her what my summer was like, happy to see her again, and she was gone."
More than six decades later, Henry's kindness still resonates with Bridges.
"I think that each and every one of us, we probably remember one teacher that made an impact in our lives, and she was the one for me," she said.

Bridges' story of integration was one of many from the civil rights era, but it has particularly endured. The scene of a tiny first grader being escorted to school by federal marshals also lives on in the form of the iconic Norman Rockwell painting, "The Problem We All Live With."

"It's that one lone child," Bridges said. "That innocence that we all see when we see that painting. How could that have happened to a 6-year-old? Innocence. And I think that affects each and every one of us when we see it, still to this very day."
She also believes the moment can continue to deliver a strong message to the children of today.
"And for kids, I think that they resonate with it," she said. "Every kid remembers someone not wanting to play with them, not giving them a chance. And I think that resonates with them."

title: How Halle Berry manifested boyfriend Van Hunt after 3 divorces: ‘Perfect match for me’
summary: Halle Berry, co-founder of Respin, opened up about her love life on TODAY with Jenna & Friends and revealed how she manifested her boyfriend, Van Hunt.
story: Halle Berry manifested her boyfriend, Van Hunt.

During a Feb. 18 appearance on TODAY with Jenna & Friends, Berry, who also just announced her menopause initiative — Respin, revealed how she knew her beau was the one after three failed marriages, and she said it's because she "spiritually called" him up.
"I manifested him," she said, adding that she learned a lot from her exes.

"Having gone through three divorces, I finally knew what wasn't working, and I realized I was always saying to the universe what I didn't want — what I didn't want," she said. "So guess what I did? I manifested what I didn't want. So, I really had to change my thinking, and instead of thinking of what I didn't want, I had to get intentional with what I did want.
"What was my perfect partner? What would he be like, feel like? What walk of life would he have come from? Who would he be? How would he treat me? I got very granular with it, and then he showed up."
"It was the perfect match for me," she added.

Berry, who was previously wed to David Justice in the '90s; Eric Benét in the early 2000s; and Olivier Martinez from 2013 until filing for divorce in 2015, explained that she would've been content on being alone if she didn't find real love with Hunt.

"If it didn't come, I would have been good just to raise my kids," she said. "After three divorces, you kind of go, 'I'm just going to be alone,' and I was ready to do that. I was done. I knew that if the right person didn't show up for me, I'd be better off going at it alone. But this is the power of manifestation. We can manifest any reality we want."
Berry and Hunt have been romantically linked since 2020. In a 2022 interview with AARP, she said they connected during the coronavirus pandemic when they spent months talking on the phone.
“We talked for hours and hours and hours and hours and never got tired. I fell in love with his mind, his conversation. I realized: I really like him,” she said.
In April 2021, Berry and Hunt made their red carpet debut as a couple at the Oscars, and not long after, Berry started gushing about Hunt in interviews.
“I finally have a real solid love in my life,” she said in a November 2021 interview with Access Hollywood. “I feel like I finally figured that out.”
Most recently, Hunt took to Instagram on Valentine’s Day to pay homage to the “Monster’s Ball” actor.
“The deeper we go the more ways i find to love you,” he wrote in the caption, along with a video of moments between the pair.

title: These 25 Black women changed history forever
summary: Learn about these trailblazing Black women in history including luminaries like Kamala Harris, Maya Angelou, Michelle Obama, Aretha Franklin and Rosa Parks.
story: Harriet Tubman. Rosa Parks. Ketanji Brown Jackson. Simone Biles. These are just a handful of the many Black women whose names represent a legacy of unparalleled achievements.
These women, along with many others, are among the first to accomplish monumental milestones, subsequently paving the way for future generations to come.
To honor the contributions of these legendary trailblazers, we've compiled a list of some of the most influential Black women in history, along with the triumphs that got them there.

You'll learn about Oprah Winfrey's journey from Miss Black Tennessee to the world's first Black billionaire, as well as how Josephine Baker went from a Vaudeville dancer to a spy for the resistance during World War II.
Along with those luminaries, learn about tennis legend, Serena Williams, Nobel-Prize winner Toni Morrison, and record-breaking Grammy winner Beyoncé, among many others.

As former first lady, Michelle Obama, memorably said at the Democratic Convention in 2008, “The only limit to the height of your achievements is the reach of your dreams and your willingness to work hard for them.”
Read her story and others in honor of Black History Month and to help inspire your own journey. For these women not only helped shape the world, but have made it a better place for all.
Beyoncé

On Sept. 4, 1981, a superstar was born in Houston, Texas. Her name? Beyoncé Giselle Knowles. From an early age, it was clear that the young Knowles was blessed with a singing voice for the ages. More than that, she was oozing with charisma, talent and ambition.

By the time she was 9, Beyoncé was performing with Girls Tyme, an all-girl singing group made up of her childhood friends. After being discovered by a producer, the group competed on television's “Star Search” and the rest, as they say, is history.

As part of the group Destiny's Child, Beyoncé scored four No. 1. hits and two Grammy Awards. But that was only the beginning of her ascent. Since going solo, she's gone on to become the most-awarded female artist of all time, winning a record-breaking 35 Grammys and countless other achievements. Reigning supreme, she only needs one moniker because Beyoncé truly is Queen Bey.
Simone Biles
There's a reason gymnast Simone Biles is commonly referred to as the “GOAT” — she literally is the greatest of all time.

With 11 Olympic medals and 30 World Championship medals, Biles holds the title as being the single most decorated gymnast in history. After bringing home the Gold in the 2016 Rio Games, the young athlete notably said, “I’m not the next Usain Bolt or Michael Phelps. I’m the first Simone Biles.”

Her words would prove prophetic. Though she hit a rough patch and withdrew from the 2020 summer Olympic games in Tokyo, she returned to Paris in 2024 with a sweeping comeback that will forever be regarded as one of the most memorable returns in Olympic history.
Serena Williams
Richard Williams and Oracene Price, were determined to see their five daughters be successful. They taught themselves the game of tennis first, before coaching sisters Serena and Venus in the sport.

By the age of 14, Serena Williams went professional and the rising athlete was soon competing against some of the most elite players in the world. Though she suffered some setbacks, the young tennis player persevered, winning the women's singles tennis title at the U.S. Open in 1999.

Over the course of her storied career, Serena Williams would go on to win 23 Grand Slam singles titles and four Olympic gold medals, as well as 14 doubles Grand Slams with her sister Venus Williams, among countless other achievements.
Toni Morrison

Toni Morrison, published her first novel in 1970 at the age of 39. The book, “The Bluest Eye,” unflinchingly explored themes of gender and internalized racism, setting Morrison on a prolific literary course that would ultimately earn the American author a Nobel Prize in literature in 1993.

The first Black woman to be honored with the distinction, Morrison would also win the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for her 1987 novel “Beloved,” along with numerous other accolades throughout her celebrated career. Included among her many notable achievements are being named a Living Legend by Congress and being bestowed with the Presidential Medal of Freedom by Barack Obama in 2012.
Josephine Baker

Born in St. Louis, Missouri, Josephine Baker's success as a Vaudeville dancer took her France, where she was lauded as one of the country's most popular performers. During World War II, Baker became a spy for the French resistance, passing on critical Nazi information to aid the war effort.

Upon returning to the U.S., Baker found herself the target of discrimination and threw herself into fighting racism and injustice at home. Baker was one of two women speakers at the March on Washington in 1963, having spoke just before Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech.
Oprah Winfrey

Oprah Winfrey began her career competing in beauty pageants before transitioning to broadcasting, where she found success as host of the Chicago TV talk show "People Are Talking." Her popularity led Winfrey to launch "The Oprah Winfrey Show," which aired for 25 years and established Winfrey as a media mogul.

After founding her own production company and television network, Winfrey would go on to become the first Black woman billionaire in the U.S. One of the most recognizable names in the world, Winfrey has notably used her accomplishments for philanthropic endeavors spanning the globe.
Mae Jemison

Born the youngest of three children in Decatur, Alabama, Mae Jemison was a student of science before going on to serve as a medical officer in the Peace Corps and establish her own practice as a doctor. Inspired by the Apollo moon trips but discouraged by the lack of female astronauts, Jemison pivoted careers and, in 1987, applied to NASA.

Out of more than 2,000 applicants, Jemison was selected to train at Kennedy Space Center. On Sept. 12, 1992, Jemison boarded the space shuttle "Endeavor" and along with six other astronauts, she orbited the earth. Her trip to the stars landed Jemison in the history books as the first Black woman in space.
Shirley Chisholm

Shirley Chisholm became a household name after becoming the first Black woman to be elected to the United States Congress in 1968. A native of Brooklyn, New York, Chisholm served seven terms in Congress and made inroads by helping to expand the food stamp program. She also introduced legislation to benefit racial and gender inequality, and became a founding member of the Congressional Black Caucus.

In 1972, Chisholm made history again as the first Black candidate to seek the nomination for President of the United States and the first woman to bid for the Democratic Party's presidential nomination. Though she was ultimately unsuccessful, her history-making accomplishments were acknowledged with a Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015.
Bessie Coleman

A Texas native, Bessie Coleman dreamt of flying planes. However, as a Black woman in the 1920s, getting her pilot's license in the U.S. was nothing short of impossible. That didn't stop the would-be aviator who, in the face of adversity, learned to speak French, then left to train in France, where Black people were permitted to become aviators. Within seven months, Coleman officially became a pilot, making her the first Black woman to do so.

However, flying wasn't enough for Coleman, who also wanted to perform stunts. After training with the German military aces, Coleman successfully became a "barnstormer," or pilot who did stunts at airshows. Tragically, Coleman died in an air accident in 1926 at the age of 34.
Elizabeth Freeman

Freeman, also known as Mumbet, was a nurse and midwife who successfully sued Massachusetts for her freedom in 1781, becoming the first African American enslaved woman to win a freedom suit in the state. Her suit helped lead to the permanent abolition of slavery in the state of Massachusetts.
Harriet Tubman

American abolitionist Harriet Tubman is best known for her efforts to move slaves to liberation in the Underground Railroad, a network of antislavery activists. Her legacy is indelible in the movement to abolish slavery, as she is documented to have made approximately 13 trips through the Underground Railroad, leading dozens of slaves to freedom and was never caught, despite a $40,000 reward for her capture.
Tubman is also the first Black woman to serve in the military after helping the Union Army during the Civil War.
Ida B. Wells

Ida B. Wells was a prominent Black investigative journalist, educator and activist in the early civil rights movement. She was one of the founders of the NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People), and led a powerful anti-lynching crusade in the U.S. in the 1890s.
Rosa Parks

Rosa Parks, a trailblazer known for her courageous participation in the Montgomery Bus Boycott, ignited the movement against racial segregation on public transit. Her defiance to give up her seat led to her arrest on Dec. 1, 1955, but led to revolutionary change. The United States Congress has since honored her as “the first lady of civil rights” and “the mother of the freedom movement.”
Maya Angelou

Maya Angelou has a distinct voice as a Black writer and activist. She left a legacy with her large body of work, including memoirs, poems, essays and plays. She rose to fame in 1969 after the publication of “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” one of her autobiographies detailing her early years as a young Black woman.
Nina Simone

Nina Simone possessed a unique raspy voice and had a massive impact on the jazz community, as well as the civil rights movement. In her early years, Simone changed her name from Eunice Kathleen Waymon, her birth name, to her new alias, Nina Simone, to disguise herself from her family while trying to forge her career in jazz as a pianist and singer. Between 1958 and 1974, Simone recorded more than 40 albums, leaving an indelible mark on music.
Audre Lorde

Audre Lorde made incredible contributions to feminist literature. In her writings, she highlights her experience being a Black lesbian woman and confronts issues of racism, homophobia, classism and misogyny, giving voice to other Black female writers and activists.
Wangari Maathai

Wangari Maathai was the first Black African woman to receive a Nobel Peace Prize for her efforts in environmental conservation. In the 1970s, she founded the Green Belt Movement, an environmental non-governmental organization focused on environmental conservation and women’s rights. She was also an elected member of Parliament and served as assistant minister for Environment and Natural Resources between 2003 and 2005.
Aretha Franklin

The “Queen of Soul" was ranked No.1 in Rolling Stone’s “200 Greatest Singers of All Time” and it’s been said that no one understood soul music better than Aretha Franklin. Inspiring generations of singers after her, including Mary J. Blige and Whitney Houston, Franklin was also the very first female artist to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 1987.
Marsha P. Johnson

Marsha P. Johnson, born Malcolm Michaels Jr., was the first self-identified, drag queen in the U.S. She was one of the first openly gay liberation activists and a key figure in the Stonewall riots in 1969. When asked what the "p" in her name stood for, she responded, "Pay it no mind," and continued to use that phrase when asked about her gender identity.
Ruby Bridges

Ruby Bridges is an American activist who helped the civil rights movement in Louisiana. She was the first child to desegregate William Frantz Elementary School, an all-white school in Louisiana, which she was selected to attend based on her displayed intelligence at just six years old. She also was later painted by Norman Rockwell and is now celebrated as a courageous Black woman who continued to fight for equal rights throughout her life.
Kamala Harris

Kamala Harris was the 49th vice president of the United States, serving in the White House from 2021 to 2025. She stands as the first female vice president in American history, the highest-ranking female official in US history — and is the first Black and Asian American to hold the position.
Michelle Obama

Not only was Michelle Obama the first African American woman to serve as the first lady of the United States, but she also continues to be a source of inspiration through her efforts to promote health and wellness for kids in America. Her story in her best-selling books "Becoming" and "The Light We Carry" encourage generations of women to dream big and never give up.
Tarana Burke

Tarana Burke is best known for organizing the #MeToo movement in 2006 as a means for victims of sexual violence to share their experiences with others, forming an alliance among survivors. Named Person of the Year by TIME magazine in 2017, Burke has spent her life empowering women to share their stories and fight against sexual assault with the slogan "empowerment through empathy."
Laverne Cox

The actress, activist and LGBT advocate is praised for her role on Netflix's "Orange Is the New Black" as Sophia Burset. She was the first transgender woman to be nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award in any acting category, and in June 2014, Cox became the first transgender woman to appear on the cover of TIME magazine.
Ketanji Brown Jackson

In April 2022, Ketanji Brown Jackson made history as the first Black woman appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court. As a young woman, she loved the law and set her sights on Harvard University. After being discouraged by a high school guidance counselor, Jackson not only graduated magna cum laude from the university, but went on to attend Harvard Law School and served as editor of the “Harvard Law Review.”

title: Justin Sylvester shocks Jenna with a surprise confession: 'Justin! What is happening here?'
summary: Justin Sylvester revealed on Today with Jenna and Friends that he is in a new relationship. See Jenna's shocked reaction.
story: It takes guts to say “I love you” first, but sometimes, it can be the start of something wonderful. Just ask Justin Sylvester.
While co-hosting “TODAY with Jenna & Friends” on Feb. 18, the E! News co-host shared some exciting news with Jenna Bush Hager and, in doing so, hard launched his new relationship.

It all happened while Jenna and Sylvester were chatting about Selena Gomez’s new single, “Scared of Loving You.” In the song, Gomez reveals that she said “I love you first” early on in her relationship with her now fiancé Benny Blanco.
“Did you say ‘I love you’ first?” Sylvester asked Jenna about her relationship with husband Henry Hager.
“No, I didn’t say ‘I love you’ first, but I did propose first. And he said no,” she replied.
Jenna went on to explain that she had had a few drinks when her now husband first said “I love you.”
﻿“And I said, ‘Me too! Let’s get married.’ And my sister was dancing with us and she just slowly danced away. She was like, ‘I’ll let you two do this,’” she recalled.
Sylvester then opened up about a time he “did something really crazy.”
“This is why I don’t talk on the phone and text at the same time anymore,” he said, setting the scene.
The TV host then recalled a conversation he had with a romantic interest.

“I was talking to a guy that I was kind of dating at the time. (We were) just starting out. It was fresh,” he said. “And you know when you’re on the phone with your girlfriends, you’re like, ‘Oh I love you. Catch you later.’ And he said, ‘Bye.’ And I said, ‘I love you. Catch you later.’”
Sylvester noted he was texting with another friend while talking on the phone and he somehow got his wires crossed.
“And he gasped, and I hung up the phone. And then he calls back and I was like, ‘I can’t do this. You cannot say anything,’” he said.
Luckily, Sylvester’s crush felt the same way about him.
“He was like, ‘I love you too and I was going to tell you that I love you as well.’ And it was a really big moment,” he said.
“But y’all aren’t together anymore,” Jenna added.
“We are still together,” Sylvester replied then laughed.
Shocked to hear the news, Jenna exclaimed, “Justin! What is happening here?”
“In Louisiana right now, my mother has just dropped her Folgers all over my sister and her child,” Sylvester joked.
“My mom might have dropped her Folgers too,” Jenna said, referring to her mother, Laura Bush, who watches the show.
“Laura, I’m sorry,” Sylvester teased. “Don’t do it.”
Jenna was curious to know why her co-host hadn’t told her the good news before. He admitted that he “didn’t know” if he was going to talk about it on air.
“How does (your boyfriend) feel that you’ve just launched in a public place? This is a public launch,” Jenna said.
“Well, thank God he gets (this show) in LA, so I have three hours to tell him,” he said.
“Let’s get that text going,” Jenna teased. “Wait, so your mistaken ‘I love you’ actually just got it all going.”
“Yeah, it kind of got it fast tracked. And I kind of freaked out and maybe ignored him for two days. But yeah, it was great,” he said.
“I’m proud of you,” Jenna said.
Sylvester then spoke about his new relationship.
“It’s been an interesting ride for sure. It’s been the best six months,” he said.
The TV host then joked about the duration of his relationship.
“And I know you guys at home are thinking, ‘Six months?’ But in gay years, that’s like six years. So we are deep. I have two kids at this point,” he said.

title: Jason Momoa drops epic pic dancing with Meryl Streep after their ‘SNL50’ cameos
summary: Jason Momoa posted a photo of him and Meryl Streep dancing at the “SNL50” after-party following their respective cameos in skits on the show.
story: You may have enjoyed seeing Jason Momoa and Meryl Streep appear on “SNL50” this past weekend, but you’re going to love seeing them at the after-party.
On Feb. 17, Momoa posted a bunch of photos from the bash that followed the “Saturday Night Live” 50th anniversary special on his Instagram page, including a shot of him and the Oscar winner dancing.
The duo lean back with their arms out, while the “Aquaman” star sports a playful scowl and Streep shows a hint of a smile. Fans loved the image of the unlikely pair cutting a rug.
“You and Meryl is the best!” one person cheered.
“You and Meryl dancing ✨️,” wrote another fan.
“Momoa and Meryl Streep project...someone make that happen please!” begged someone else.
In addition, Momoa, who also posted a picture of him and Streep smiling at the camera, shared photos from the party with Bill Murray, Chevy Chase, Jerry Seinfeld, Kristen Wiig and Anya Taylor-Joy.

Momoa was featured during an audience Q&A segment of the show, when “SNL” alums Tina Fey and Amy Poehler called up Donna Richards to honor her for her work dressing the guest host each week since 1997.
“She has seen every celebrity here in their underpants,” Fey joked before asking her for her favorite.
“Jason Momoa!” she replied before Fey could even finish asking the question, drawing laughs.
About four minutes later, Momoa, seated in the audience, stood up to ask a question about Donna.
“Yeah, that Donny lady — uh, she like to travel, or, like, what’s her vibe?” he asked, getting laughs from the crowd.
“You’ll have to ask her,” Fey responded. Richards, incidentally, also appeared in the carousel of photos Momoa posted on Instagram.

Streep was one of the evening’s breakout stars, appearing in her first-ever “Saturday Night Live” sketch. She played Kate McKinnon’s mother in the latest “Close Encounter” sketch, in which they hilariously recall their experiences being abducted by aliens while being interviewed at the Pentagon.

It's somewhat surprising Streep had never been on "SNL" before. In a sense, both she and the show came of age and grew at the same time. "SNL" premiered in 1975, while she notched the first of her 21 Oscar nominations for 1978's "The Deer Hunter." A three-time Academy Award winner, her most recent nomination came for "The Post," which was released in 2017.

title: See Maria Shriver’s incredible reaction to son Patrick Schwarzenegger’s ‘White Lotus’ casting news
summary: Patrick Schwarzenegger shared an Instagram video telling Maria Shriver and Katherine Schwarzenegger he was going to Thailand to film "The White Lotus."
story: Warning: This post contains spoilers for “The White Lotus” Season 3.
Patrick Schwarzenegger couldn't wait to tell his family that he was headed to Thailand to shoot Season 3 of "The White Lotus" — but he had to.
The star of the hit HBO show's third season shared the moment he told his mom, TODAY contributor Maria Shriver, and sister Katherine Schwarzenegger he had been cast and had to go to Thailand.
His family was seated at a restaurant together as they started guessing what the 31-year-old was about to tell them, according to a video he posted on Instagram Feb. 16.
"You're pregnant," Shriver says to the person behind the camera, most likely Patrick Schwarzenegger's fiancée, Abby Champion, who shouts, "No!"
"I'm just really not supposed to tell people," Patrick Schwarzenegger says. "It's fine if you guys know, but, I'll be going to Thailand."
Shriver nearly jumps out of her seat and starts screaming at the table, while Katherine Schwarzenegger sinks back in her seat.
The video then cuts to Shriver and her son hugging, as Katherine Schwarzenegger points to her tears.
"You're going to make me cry," Patrick Schwarzenegger says, wiping away his own tears once his mom breaks away from the embrace.
"I'm so happy for you," Shriver repeatedly says as the family breaks down in tears while also laughing.
Patrick Schwarzenegger also shared more about the moment in the caption of his post.

"At first, I was told I had to keep It a secret, but my family kept noticing me acting weird. Maria thought Abby and I were pregnant," he said, adding a crying laughing emoji. "She might have been happier than I was!!"
He explained the crying became a "domino effect."
He added that his family members are big fans of "The White Lotus" and that they would "mess" with him and say he needed to get on the show.
"Anyways it’s a special moment when you get to celebrate with people you love," he said. "It was one of those dream come true moments for me."
He thanked the show's creator, Mike White, as well as the casting director, Meredith Tucker, for taking a chance on him.

"I hope you all enjoy the show as much as we did. We put a lot of hard work into making It," he said. "I’m only a small piece of the pie, and the other actors and actresses on the show are truly brilliant people & actors. Was a masterclass getting to learn from them."
He ended the caption with the current season's tagline: "Welcome to The White Lotus in Thailand."
While the actor's father, Arnold Schwarzenegger, didn't appear to attend the outing, he did give his son a special shoutout after attending the show's premiere in Los Angeles.

"I was so pumped to take a break from filming to celebrate @patrickschwarzenegger at the White Lotus Season 3 premiere," he wrote in the caption of a Feb. 11 Instagram post. "What a show! I could claim to be surprised to find out he has a nude scene, but what can I say — the apple doesn’t fall far from the tree. Don’t miss it this Sunday — trust me."

The first episode of the show premiered Feb. 16, and yes, Patrick Schwarzenegger's character, Saxon Ratliff, does appear in the nude, after an extremely awkward conversation with his younger brother, Lochlan.
Patrick Schwarzenegger previously shared a bit about his character in an interview with TODAY.com.
“Saxon’s a very fit guy and cares a lot about what he puts in his body and about all his health and wellness and working out and stuff,” he said.
He added the character is “completely different” from himself, but there was one place of overlap.

“It’s a character that’s working for his dad, living in his dad’s shadows and trying to make a name for himself,” he said. “So, there were similarities there for myself that I could, you know, draw upon.”

title: Ryan Reynolds seems to poke fun at ‘It Ends With Us’ lawsuit involving wife Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni during ‘SNL50’
summary: Ryan Reynolds seemed to joke about the drama involving Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni over “It Ends With Us” during “SNL50" anniversary special.
story: Known for his sense of humor, Ryan Reynolds seemed to joke about the legal drama surrounding his wife, Blake Lively, and Justin Baldoni over their movie “It Ends With Us” during “SNL50" on Feb. 16.
During an interactive Q&A-style skit hosted by “SNL” alums Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, Reynolds appeared in the audience and stood up to ask a question.
"Ryan Reynolds, how’s it going?” Poehler asked the “Deadpool” star.
“Great,” he replied before taking a beat to continue.
“Why, what have you heard?” he asked, alluding to the “It Ends With Us” drama.
The audience laughed, while Lively looked up at him.
Fey and Poehler, meanwhile, raised their hands, pleading ignorance, like they hadn’t heard anything about Reynolds or Lively that may have generated headlines in recent weeks.

Reynolds continued by asking if it was safe to eat the material used to make the Coneheads, the long heads worn by Dan Aykroyd, Jane Curtin and Laraine Newman in the popular sketches from the early years of “SNL.”
“Edible? No, and based on them being made in 1975, I’d assume that they’re highly toxic,” Fey said.
“So, if somebody, hypothetically, took a couple of nibbles backstage and, you know, got excited, should they go to the hospital?” Reynolds asked.

The eight-minute skit featured a wide array of celebrities who asked the "SNL" duo questions, including Quinta Brunson, Jon Hamm, Nate Bargatze, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Keith Richards, Bad Bunny, Ray Romano, Jason Momoa and Peyton Manning.

Reynolds and Lively’s appearance comes as Lively and Baldoni are engaged in a public legal battle. They will head to trial beginning March 9, 2026. Lively starred in “It Ends With Us” alongside Baldoni, who also directed the 2024 film, which is based on the bestselling novel by Colleen Hoover.

Lively has sued Baldoni in federal court, accusing him of sexual harassment while they shot the movie and then conducting a smear campaign against her in the media. The suit came after she filed a  sexual harassment complaint against him with the California Civil Rights Department this past December, according to court documents obtained by NBC News.

Baldoni fired back by suing Lively, Reynolds, Leslie Sloane and Sloane's PR firm in a U.S. district court in New York for $400 million for defamation. Lively's representatives responded in a statement to NBC News at the time, saying Baldoni's lawsuit is "another chapter in the abuser playbook" and "evidence will show that the cast and others had their own negative experiences" with Baldoni and his production company, Wayfarer.

Baldoni also sued The New York Times for libel, after it published an article in December 2024 about Lively’s allegations. The Times said in a Jan. 1 statement that it plans to "vigorously defend against the lawsuit."

title: Aubrey Plaza appears on ‘SNL50’ in her first public appearance since husband Jeff Baena’s death
summary: Aubrey Plaza made her first public appearance since husband Jeff Baena's death when she was on "SNL50," for the 50th anniversary of "Saturday Night Live."
story: If you or someone you know is in crisis, call or text 988 to reach the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline or chat live at 988lifeline.org. You can also visit SpeakingOfSuicide.com/resources for additional support.

Aubrey Plaza made her first public appearance since her husband, director Jeff Baena, died last month. The “Parks and Recreation” star appeared briefly on "SNL50" on Feb. 16 when she introduced a musical performance.
Plaza welcomed Miley Cyrus and Brittany Howard to the "SNL" stage before the duo performed “Nothing Compares 2 U," which was written by Prince and later recorded by Sinéad O'Connor.
“Ladies and gentlemen, Miley Cyrus and Brittany Howard,” Plaza said, while holding a microphone as she stood in the audience with her back to the stage.
Plaza was wearing a blazer over a tie-dyed shirt. She previously spoke about her late husband's interest in tie-dying, noting that the style was part of their outfits when they got married.

“Jeff got really into tie-dying during the quarantine, so I decided that Jeff and I were going to wear tie-dye pajamas that he had made for us,” Plaza said on “The Drew Barrymore Show” in 2021. “I made a love altar in the backyard of all of our love objects. It was very witchcore, but it happened.”
Plaza has not been seen in public since Baena died by suicide on Jan. 3.
“This is an unimaginable tragedy. We are deeply grateful to everyone who has offered support,” his family said in a statement following his death. “Please respect our privacy during this time.”
Baena co-wrote the 2004 movie “I Heart Huckabees,” created the 2021 Showtime anthology series “Cinema Toast” and directed the 2020 Netflix film “Horse Girl.”
He and Plaza also collaborated over the years on several projects including “Life After Beth,” “The Little Hours” and “Spin Me Round.”
When Brady Corbet won the Golden Globe Award for best director for “The Brutalist” on Jan. 5, he mentioned Baena and Plaza in his acceptance speech while honoring people he knew who recently died.
“And finally, tonight my heart is with Aubrey Plaza and Jeff’s family. Goodnight,” Corbet said.
Plaza, who was famously an NBC page, previously hosted "SNL" in January 2023.

title: ‘The Bachelor’ contestants 2025: Meet the 25 women chosen for Grant Ellis
summary: Read on for bios about the 25 women on Grant Ellis's season of The Bachelor. Here's what to know about the contestants for season 29, premiering Jan. 27.
story: After a later than usual start, Grant Ellis' season of “The Bachelor” has arrived.

Ellis, a 31-year-old day trader and former professional basketball player, was named the next lead of the long-running reality dating show in August. He is making history as the second-ever Black male lead after former “Bachelor” Matt James handed out roses in Season 25.

Bachelor Nation first fell in love with Ellis when he appeared on Jenn Tran’s season of “The Bachelorette” last summer. He opened up to Tran about repairing his relationship with his father and the two bonded while speaking about their families. But she broke up with him before he could make it to “Hometowns” week. He wasn’t heartbroken for too long, though, as he was announced as the Season 29 lead the night of his elimination.

When the show premiered Monday, Jan. 27, one contestant described him as “tall, handsome, smart. Hottest bachelor ever." Another called him as “authentic” and serious about finding a lifelong partner.
Of course, there will also be plenty of tears and drama during Ellis’ journey to find love. So who is hoping to receive his final rose? Get to know the cast of 25 ladies below.
Alexe Godin
Age: 27
Job: Pediatric speech therapist
Hometown: New Brunswick, Canada
Instagram: alexe.godin
Alexe is a big animal lover after growing up on a farm. She is also fluent in French and loves to watch cooking competition shows.
Status: Still in the running.
Alli Jo Hinkes
Age: 30
Job: Boxing trainer
Hometown: Manalapan, New Jersey
Instagram: a.cup.of.jo_
As a trainer, Alli Jo loves to stay active. She likes the beach, spends her free time planning trips and wishes to visit Dubai one day to go shopping.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 3.
Allyshia Gupta
Age: 29
Job: Interior designer
Hometown: Tampa, Florida
Instagram: allyshiagupta

“The Bachelor” franchise is continuing its recent trend of casting former pageant queens with the addition of Allyshia, who was Miss California 2020. Allyshia enjoys a day at the beach, horses and dogs and all things romance.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 2.
Bailey Brown
Age: 27
Job: Social media manager
Hometown: Atlanta, Georgia
Instagram: baileytaylorbrown
Bailey is the proud owner of a toy poodle named Easa. She is hoping to find a guy who is funny, thoughtful and family-oriented, so let’s see if Grant is her perfect match.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 3.
Beverly Ortega
Age: 30
Job: Insurance salesperson
Hometown: Howard Beach, New York
Instagram: beverlybortega
Beverly’s parents have been married for 30-plus years and she is hoping their love story will inspire her own. She is also a big fan of romantic movies like “Titanic” and “The Princess Diaries.”
Status: Went home for personal reasons in Episode 3.
Carolina Quixano
Age: 28
Job: Public relations producer
Hometown: Guaynabo, Puerto Rico
Instagram: itscarolinasofia
Carolina can speak three languages: English, Spanish and French. Her childhood crush was Joe Jonas and she hopes that one day Golden Globes host Nikki Glaser will roast her.
Status: Still in the running.
Chloie Costello
Age: 27
Job: Model
Hometown: New York, New York
Instagram: chloie_costello

Chloie grew up in the Midwest but relocated to New York to pursue her dream of becoming a fashion model. She loves watching movies like “You’ve Got Mail” and “When Harry Met Sally” and sipping on a dirty martini.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 3.
Christina Smith
Age: 26
Job: Marketing director
Hometown: Fargo, North Dakota
Instagram: christinakelly

Christina is a daredevil who would be willing to jump out of an airplane, so a bungee jump date — a “Bachelor” franchise staple — might be in her future if she sticks around long enough. When she is in the mood for something less intense, she can be found spending time with her friends at the lake or planning a wine night.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Dina Lupancu
Age: 31
Job: Attorney
Hometown: Chicago, Illinois
Instagram: dinalupancu
Dina is one of 11 siblings and is hoping to find a man who is family-oriented, as well. Dina describes herself as “mysterious.”
Status: Still in the running.
Ella Del Rosario
Age: 25
Job: Luxury travel host
Hometown: Los Angeles, California
Instagram: elladelro
Ella is from a Filipino family and hopes to teach her future partner about her culture. She also loves to invite family and friends over to eat and watch basketball, one of Grant’s favorite sports.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 2.
J’Nae Squires-Horton
Age: 28
Job: Account coordinator
Hometown: Colorado Springs, Colorado
Instagram: heyimjnae
J’Nae and Grant already have something in common: they both played professional basketball overseas. Aside from shooting hoops on the court, J’Nae also likes to dance and take pictures.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Juliana Pasquarosa
Age: 28
Job: Client service associate
Hometown: Newton, Massachusetts
Instagram: julianapasquarosa

Juliana was raised in a big Italian family and is looking for a love similar to the connection her parents, who were high school sweethearts, still share. She likes listening to Frank Sinatra and dreams of opening a dog-friendly bar.
Status: Still in the running.
Kelsey Curtis
Age: 26
Job: Interior designer
Hometown: Brooklyn, New York
Instagram: kelise1_

Kelsey has visited almost every continent and spends her free time trying new restaurants and vacationing in Martha’s Vineyard during the summers. She wishes to meet Kris Jenner so that the matriarch can teach her about “empire building.”
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Kyleigh Henrich
Age: 26
Job: Retail manager
Hometown: Wilmington, North Carolina
Instagram: kyleigh_henrich
Kyleigh owns a mini Goldendoodle named Bella and once lived in Uganda for four months. She likes to line dance, surf, play pickleball and watch her favorite movie, “Pearl Harbor.”
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Litia Garr
Age: 31
Job: Venture capitalist
Hometown: Salt Lake City, Utah
Instagram: litiagarr

Litia’s three dream qualities in a partner are honesty, vulnerability and someone who is family-oriented. Like Grant, she is a fan of basketball and also likes to watch football and water polo, ride horses and play board games.
Status: Still in the running.
Natalie Phillips
Age: 25
Job: Ph.D. student
Hometown: Louisville, Kentucky
Instagram: natalie_phillips_

Natalie’s parents have been married for over 30 years and she admires their partnership. Besides studying, she spends her spare time playing with her dog, Tuck, watching rom-coms and cheering for her football team, the Seattle Seahawks.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 4.
Neicey Baxter
Age: 32
Job: Pediatrician
Hometown: Blythewood, South Carolina
Instagram: neiceylyn
Neicey splits her time and knowledge between four different hospitals. When she isn’t working, she likes to try different coffees, visit farmers markets and go to football games.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Parisa Shifteh
Age: 29
Job: A pediatric behavior analyst
Hometown: Birmingham, Michigan
Instagram: parisa_marie7
Parisa enjoys cooking, traveling and nights spent indulging in charcuterie boards. She also has a rock collection and can spend hours scrolling on TikTok.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 4.
Radhika Gupta
Age: 28
Job: Attorney
Hometown: New York, New York
Instagram: radhi_gupta
Radhika stems from a close-knit Indian family and wants to share her family traditions with her future partner. She likes to cook with her mom, go shopping and host dance parties.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Rebekah Garrett
Age: 31
Job: ICU nurse
Hometown: Dallas, Texas
Instagram: rawrbekah
Rebekah likes to travel and would like to visit different places around the world with her future partner. She also enjoys animals and playing Scrabble.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 2.
Rose Sombke
Age: 27
Job: Registered nurse
Hometown: Chicago, Illinois
Instagram: rosesombke

Rose spends her days going to the beach, exploring new places and enjoying nights out on the town despite being a self-described “terrible dancer.” She is a big fan of Julie Andrews and Formula 1 racing.
Status: Still in the running.
Sarafiena Watkins
Age: 29
Job: Associate media director
Hometown: New York, New York
Instagram: sarafienawatkins
Sarafiena is ready to find a partner to settle down with and start a family. But for now, she enjoys spontaneity and books trips on a whim when she isn’t dancing or watching “Grey’s Anatomy.”
Status: Still in the running.
Savannah Quinn
Age: 27
Job: Wedding planner
Hometown: Charlottesville, Virginia
Instagram: actual_sav_quinn
Savannah is ready to turn the plot of “The Wedding Planner” into a reality and head down the aisle. She wants to find a man who is loyal, caring and talkative.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 1.
Vicky Nyamuswa
Age: 28
Job: Nightclub server
Hometown: Las Vegas, Nevada
Instagram: vickyvic_
Vicky used to work as an NFL cheerleader and still enjoys watching football. She dreams of living on a vineyard in Italy and likes to spend time with her Chihuahua, Winnie.
Status: Eliminated in Episode 2.
Zoe McGrady
Age: 27
Job: Tech engineer and model
Hometown: New York, New York
Instagram: zoe.mcgrady

Zoe was the first female wrestler to compete on her high school team before attending Duke University and graduating with a degree in mechanical engineering. During her free time, she likes to go boating, surf, ice skate and eat tacos.
Status: Still in the running.

title: Willie recalls Jenna's dad thinking he actually said ‘strategery’ from 'SNL' impression
summary: Willie Geist revisited when Jenna Bush Hager's dad, former President George W. Bush, thought he said "strategery" from Will Ferrell's impersonation of him as part of a "Saturday Night Live" skit.
story: Former President George W. Bush had a good laugh from Will Ferrell's "Saturday Night Live" impersonation of him — even when he took it more literally than intended.
In a conversation with the former president’s daughter, TODAY’s Jenna Bush Hager, Sunday TODAY host Willie Geist recalled when he was invited to Dallas, Texas, for an “SNL” event Bush hosted.
At the event, Willie interviewed "SNL" creator and executive producer Lorne Michaels, who spoke about Ferrell's iconic impression of the former president.

“Your dad, I have to say, was sitting in the front row watching the clips and not laughing politely about himself, but like head thrown back, like ‘Oh that Will Ferrell, he’s so good,’” Willie told Jenna while on TODAY with Jenna & Friends on Feb. 17.
Willie told Jenna that a group went to dinner after the event, which resulted in a “now-famous” exchange between Bush and Michaels.

“Your dad says to Lorne Michaels, ‘I sure gave you a lot of material over the years.’ And he said ‘Like strategery. Remember when I said strategery?’” Willie said. “And Lorne Michaels looked at me and we realized your dad was serious. And Lorne said, ‘You didn’t say strategery, we wrote that and Will said it.’”

“And your dad slaps the table and goes, ‘I didn’t say strategery? All these years I thought I said strategery. But you know what I did say? Misunderestimate.’ Slaps the table again,” Willie continued.
Willie said he remembers thinking, “This guy is the best,” of Bush, adding how endearing Jenna’s dad came across to the "SNL" creator.
“Lorne fell in love — if he hadn’t already — right then and there,” Willie said. “Your dad was so joyful about having been made fun of on ‘SNL.’”
Jenna told Willie she feels the role of “SNL” is both to keep “humor as part of our culture” and to keep “people in power in check.”
“Everybody should be able to laugh at themselves, no matter who you are, but even if you’re the President of the United States,” she said.
However, Jenna added that she now blames her dad whenever she mispronounces a word.
“I just say it’s part of my DNA,” she joked.
In a 2017 interview on “Jimmy Kimmel Live,” Bush recalled the same moment while having dinner with Michaels, insisting that he “damn sure said strategery.”
Host Jimmy Kimmel asked Bush if any impression of him has “ever bothered him,” to which Bush replied, “No, not at all.”

title: Why Bill Hader wasn’t at the ‘SNL’ 50th anniversary special
summary: Why didn't Bill Hader attend the 'Saturday Night Live' 50th Anniversary Special on Sunday, Feb. 16? His representative tells TODAY.com it was due to a "longstanding schedule conflict."
story: “Saturday Night Live” brought some their most notable players back for its 50th anniversary special. But fans noticed some comedians missed the big night in Studio 8H — Bill Hader being one of them.
So, why wasn't Hader, who was a cast member between 2005 and 2013, part of the "SNL" special on Sunday, Feb. 16?
A representative for Hader told TODAY.com that the comedian had "a longstanding schedule conflict," which is why he could not attend.
Fans noticed Hader's absence from the three-hour special, and took to social media to express their thoughts.
“This show had everything. Except Bill Hader’s Stefon,” one person wrote on X, referring to one of Hader’s most memorable “SNL” characters who appeared on "Weekend Update."
“Nah, how are you going to celebrate SNL 50 weekend update without Stefon. That’s a crime. Where tf is Bill Hader,” another wrote.
One X user made a photo edit with missing signs calling for Hader, writing, "BILL HADER COME HOME."
"Ok not gonna lie, it feels wrong watching the SNL 50th anniversary without Bill Hader," another person wrote.
Another unforgettable "SNL" sketch that he appeared in is "The Californians," where Hader, Kristen Wiig and Fred Armisen do a soap opera spoof with over-the-top California accents.
Online, fans missed the sketch at “SNL50,” writing, “Where’s Bill Hader? Where’s The Californians?!?”

Though the Californians trio didn't make it to the big anniversary show, Hader, Wiig and Armisen reprised their characters, Devin, Karina and Stuart, for a Volkswagen commercial that aired a few days before "SNL50."

Along with the commercial, Hader was also involved in the documentary, “Ladies & Gentlemen... 50 Years of SNL Music,” which aired in January. Hader was featured in several one-on-one interviews reminiscing on specific music memories from “SNL” over the years.

Dana Carvey, Dan Aykroyd and Colin Quinn — three more “Saturday Night Live” legends — also didn't appear to be at “SNL50,” among other comedians. TODAY.com reached out to their representatives and "SNL," but have not heard back.

title: Who is Lainey Wilson’s soon-to-be husband?
summary: Get to know Devlin “Duck” Hodges, the man who’s “Counting Chickens” with the Grammy winner and seven-time CMA Awards winner.
story: Award-winning country music star Lainey Wilson plans to two-step down the aisle with fiancé Devlin “Duck” Hodges one day soon.
The 32-year-old hitmaker has been dating the 28-year-old former football player since 2021, taking their relationship public in 2023.
Now that the two have revealed their engagement news, fans want to know all about the cowboy who’s been by Wilson’s side and inspiring some of her sweetest songs.
Read on to learn more about the honey in “Hang Tight Honey.”
He played football at Samford University
Long before Hodges fell in love with Wilson, he fell hard for his favorite sport — football.
The Kimberly, Alabama-born athlete discovered his fondness for the game back in elementary school and continued playing the sport through college.
At Samford University, he was a starter for the Bulldogs and showed major potential. In 2018, his standout offensive plays earned him the coveted Walter Payton Award.
He played for the Pittsburgh Steelers
Hodges went pro in 2019. An undrafted free agent, he was signed by the Pittsburgh Steelers and stepped in as quarterback for Mason Rudolph when he suffered an injury.
Hodges remained with the Steelers until the following season. In 2021, he signed a reserve contract with the Los Angeles Rams.
These days, he’s a ‘cheerleader’

Hodges left the NFL later that same year, then spent some time with the Canadian Football League’s Ottawa Redblacks. In 2022, he retired from professional football altogether. Now, he’s a cheerleader — of sorts.
While Hodges officially works in real estate now, according to Wilson, he’s so happy about her success in the country music spotlight, he’s genuinely content to cheer her on from the sidelines.

“Thankfully, I have found a man that is so happy that he’s with a lady that can do her own thing,” she said in a 2024 interview with Billboard. “He’s just my cheerleader. He makes it real easy and it’s fun to be able to share this part of my life that I’ve kept ... close to my chest, I guess you could say, for a while.”
He goes by ‘Duck’
Anyone who’s ever heard Wilson speak about her main man knows she refers to him exclusively by his nickname, Duck, as do many others close to him. But why?
The obvious answer might be that he earned the moniker as a result of his love of duck hunting and competitive prowess when it comes to duck calling.

According to a profile published on the Mossy Oak website, Hodges has had a passion for waterfowling since childhood, learning to hunt with his father and brother. At the age of 13, Hodges won the 2009 Junior World Duck Calling Contest, followed by a win at the Alabama State Duck Calling Championship in 2018.
According to Wilson, though, there’s more to the nickname’s story.

“If you read something online, it probably ain’t right,” she said of Hodges’ nickname during a 2023 visit to “The Bobby Bones Show.” “His college football coach was like, ‘You’re one of the best quarterbacks I’ve ever worked with. And you remind me a lot of one of my favorite quarterbacks I got to work with years ago, and we called him Duck.’ And so, him and the team just kind of started calling him Duck.”
He proposed with a multi-diamond ring
On Feb. 12, 2025, Wilson revealed that she and Hodges were engaged by sharing photos and a video clip on Instagram.
“4x4xU forever ❤️,” she wrote in the caption, referencing her loved-up single of the same name.

Though Wilson didn’t reveal how Hodges proposed, she did show off the spectacular multi-diamond ring he proposed with. In the video clip, she even walks with a limp, harking back to a comment she made last fall.
“I don’t care what shape it is, but I want to be walking with a limp,” she said of her future ring on the “Country Heat Weekly” podcast.

Even if Hodges hadn’t popped the question when he did, the couple might be engaged by now anyway. Wilson noted to Bunnie XO in a New Year’s Eve chat for CMT posted to Instagram she was prepared to step up and ask him.
“I might have to propose to him,” Wilson said with a laugh after her pal expressed hope for some engagement news soon. “We waitin’!”
Months before, Wilson joked about the topic to Taste of Country, saying, “I guess I’m going to have to propose to his ass, ’cause he ain’t proposed to me.”
He’s the inspiration for some of her songs
Those pre-proposal comments weren’t the only hints Wilson was ready to lock things down with Hodges. The biggest hint of all might just be her 2024 song “Counting Chickens.”

The track, from her fifth studio album, “Whirlwind,” is all about being ready for a proposal (and a wedding, home and family, too), featuring the lyrics, “Oh, and I ain’t tryin’ to scare ya/ Make you high tail fly the coop/ But I’m counting on ya, baby/ Hope you’re counting on me too.”
The song ends with a hat tip to who she’s counting on: “One chicken, two chickens, three chickens/ Oh, shoot, I think that’s a duck.”
According to Wilson, she’s penned other songs about Hodges, too, though many of those aren’t for fans’ ears.
During her chat with Taste of Country, she explained that she sings all her songs for Hodges before anyone else, including the ones “I’ve written for him that nobody else will hear.”
He’s frequently her plus-one
When Wilson opened up about Hodges to Billboard, she mentioned that he “can’t sing a lick.” But even though he’s no country crooner, he’s found himself at several music-award ceremonies.
Since going public with their relationship, Hodges has become a fixture at many of country music’s biggest events as Wilson’s date.

title: How to watch the ‘Saturday Night Live’ 50th anniversary special
summary: "Saturday Night Live" is celebrating 50 years since the sketch comedy show first aired in October 1975. Here's how to watch the three-hour special.
story: "Saturday Night Live" just celebrated 50 years since the sketch comedy show first aired in October 1975.

To mark the milestone, current and past "SNL" cast members, fellow comedians, esteemed actors, musical guests and more graced Studio 8H on Sunday, Feb. 16, to commemorate half a century of laughs with a three-hour special.

Though “SNL” has historically aired live on Saturday nights, the anniversary show took place on Sunday night. (On Saturday, Feb. 15, NBC aired a special re-broadcast of the show’s very first episode.)
Click here for a recap of “SNL50.”
Sunday's live show included guests like Tina Fey, Amy Poehler, Eddie Murphy, John Mulaney, Kate McKinnon, Maya Rudolph, Will Ferrell and more.
When was the ‘SNL’ 50th anniversary special?
"SNL50," a three-hour primetime special that aired Sunday, Feb. 16, from 8 to 11 p.m. on NBC.

Red carpet coverage began at 7 p.m. ET on NBC. Sunday TODAY host Willie Geist, as well as “SNL” alum Leslie Jones and comedian Matt Rogers, interviewed guests as they arrived at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York City.
How to re-watch the ‘SNL’ 50th anniversary special
The “SNL” anniversary special aired live Sunday evening on NBC and Peacock. (Peacock and TODAY.com share a parent company, NBCUniversal.)
Following the live taping, the special is now available for streaming on Peacock. With a cable subscription, the show can also be re-watched on NBC.

title: 'SNL' secrets: Past and present cast members reveal what really goes on behind the scenes
summary: What is performing or writing for "Saturday Night Live" really like? TODAY.com talked to past and present cast to learn what really goes on behind the scenes.
story: Shortly before "NBC's Saturday Night" lit up American TV sets on Oct. 11, 1975, producer Lorne Michaels and seven unknown actors and comedians appeared on "The Tomorrow Show," a late-night talk show with Tom Snyder, to promote their new 90-minute variety series.
"We've got eight and we're hoping for two for it to really work," Michaels deadpanned to Snyder about his new cast. "So, not all of these people will become stars."

Sitting next to him? Chevy Chase, Dan Aykroyd, Jane Curtin, Garrett Morris, Gilda Radner, John Belushi and Laraine Newman. Despite Michaels' tongue-in-cheek prediction, they would, in fact, go on to become not only stars, but legends as the original Not Ready For Prime Time Players on the soon-to-be renamed "Saturday Night Live."
